title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: In our Session there were some influential men:there was Sir James Spittal, who was knighted forbeing the first Lord Provost under the new constitution under the Reform Bill; there was CommissaryClerk Carphin, grandfather of one of our late elders,James R. Carphin; there was Mr Henderson, of theBritish Linen Bank, a big, stout man with a tree leg;there was old Mr Noble, a most worthy, godly man,who sometimes came to our house, and liked a glassof port uncommonly, but he never partook of itwithout first asking a blessing on it and on thehousehold; there was a Mr Menteith, a partner of theGlasgow house of Menteith & Co., famous as Turkeyred dyers. After he had entered the business, he wasled to be earnest in his piety, and became a studentfor the ministry; and while attending the Hall inEdinburgh, he acted as an elder with us.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: The Royal Bank, with an equestrian statue of thcfourth Earl of Hopetoun in front, is a fine building. The adjoining building—the British Linen Bank—has a frontage of isolated Corinthian columns. Inthe Old Town the most prominent feature is theCastle.
